texts.shortText: Elysia punctata var. rubropunctata Macnae, 1954: unaccepted > superseded, misidentified as Elysia viridis in Gosliner, 1987, and listed as Elysia sp. in Zsilavecz, 2007, Jones, 2008 and Branch et al., 2022

A small green- to brown-bodied sap-sucker. The body is smooth and has vivid blue spots. The head is green and may have opaque white spots. The rolled rhinophores have opaque white speckling. There are two black eyes. The paired parapodia are usually lacking in undulations and may have opaque white speckling and minute red spots. The body also has opaque white speckling. There exists an albino morph, with blue spots, red dots and opaque white speckling, but this is rare.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern West Coast to southern Wild Coast, intertidal to 19 m.
This species is found on various species of green seaweeds in the genera Codium and Bryopsis on which they are camouflaged.

This species feeds on green seaweeds in the genera Codium and Bryopsis, using their ingested chloroplasts to produce sugars for its own nutrition (kleptoplasty), a rare behaviour of Sacoglossa species. These solar-powered sea slugs line their slugs digestive tract with chloroplasts from the algae which then provides resources through photosynthesis.
This species is hermaphroditic. The egg ribbon is a flat spiral of one or two whorls, made up of distinct greenish-white eggs.
The species is distinguished from other taco slugs by its relatively short parapodia and its narrow foot.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 214).

Gosliner, T (1987). Nudibranchs of Southern Africa: A Guide to the Opisthobranch Molluscs of Southern Africa. Sea Challengers, California (p. 51).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 758, 805).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 132).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 21).
